it's so and after this process of going

that github was failing to serve that

snapshots is currently in CSI so what
I'm trying to say here is that open
collaboration promotes consensus so if
you're looking for consensus on a
specification it's helpful to have a lot
of people working out in the open
transparently and collaborating together
so next I want to talk a little bit
about some of the lessons learned wet on
developing an ecosystem to help people
use the specification so the problem
here is that the specification isn't
actually just an RPC boundary it's
actually a large body of text kind of
defining the usage different error codes
and the control flow of what happens
when you're using this specification so
as with any text as with any large body
of text people from different
backgrounds and different mindsets can
read the exact same words on the page
and actually come to very different
interpretations of the specification so
how did we solve this problem or
partially solve this problem well we
actually developed this thing called CSI
sanity which what that is is kind of a
light conformance test suite just to
mean
make sure that the basic specifications
are met so this is by no means a full
end-to-end test suite it doesn't check
any of the back-end implementations
right it's agnostic to vendor it just
checks that like for example if you're
doing this certain thing this certain
error comes back alright and this is
great to catch subtleties and other
pieces that you forgot and so when I ran
the CSI sanity for the first time on the
GCE driver
I was actually failing about 10 tests
out of 12 and those were hard to catch
otherwise so and I actually had to fix
all of those to become CSI spec
compliant all right so this is a real
fake example of what CSI sanity test
failures look like in my case this RPC
call is returning an error code 3 which
means not found when it should actually
be returning an error code 5 which is
invalid argument ok so this might
actually seem really inconsequential not
super important but I'd actually like to
dig into it a little bit more and prove
to you that it actually is very
important that we agree on whether it
should be not found or invalid argument
so for this was a real thing that
happened actually by the way for the
specification and a real argument that
we had but on a strict definition of the
spec for certain cases it's actually
fairly easy to make the argument either
way right like if you wanted to return
not found you could make that argument
if you want to make invalid argument you
could also make that argument on strict
definition of the specification so
different drivers were actually
implementing the same case with
different error codes but CSI sanity was
able to kind of catch that and what I
noticed was that previous error it had
some error and I was like why is that
happening and this is kind of important
because when we have an RPC boundary
small inconsistencies can actually cause
different trigger different behaviors
upstream right so in this case if my
driver was to return invalid argument
maybe the person or the container
Orchestrator consuming it on the other
end interprets that as a user error and
surfaces it to the user
for them to change their argument
whereas if we return and not found error
maybe kubernetes then interprets it as
needing to create an object or something
in response to that to make sure that we
could actually find that object all
right so it's possible that these small
inconsistencies can make very large
changes upstream so what I'm trying to
say is that conformance tools maintain
consistency okay so if you want
consistency across all interpretations
of your specification maybe you should
make a conformance tool and lastly I
want to discuss one more thing which is
lessons about getting adoption for your
extensions and so the kind of problem
here is that a lot of and this will be
shared with other extension mechanisms
as well but a lot of kubernetes
extensions are actually going to be and
in our case is a replacement for
existing functionality okay and this
pattern might pop up again so we
currently support the old way of doing
things while also supporting container
storage interface and so as a user it's
it's kind of difficult to get users to
move to the new way of doing things this
extensions way when the alternative just
works right so we want users to go from
this state of kind of confusion to a
happy user right and how are we going to
do that well we're still in the process
so this is a little bit fuzzy but our
strategy so far has been to add value to
see add more value to CSI to get users
to move independently so I want to make
it very clear that we're still
supporting entry plugins if there any
bugs or problems we still patch those
but new features on drivers
get added to the container storage
interface for example snapshots so
snapshots are pretty important
functionality a lot of people really
want it and we're adding it to CSI but
not to entry plugins and currently this
is in alpha so in the future more
features like this will be added where
we're adding new functionality to CSI
and not really adding it to the older
version and hopefully that will drive
user adoption that will add enough value
to see a side that people will move over
another thing that we're doing that's
currently in flight is a new test
framework for CSI that kind of lets you
plug your own driver in to existing
kubernetes e to e tests for storage so
that every driver can now run the
kubernetes e to e suite and these are
tests that the kubernetes maintainer x'
have kind of decided are a set of things
that we want volume volumes in workloads
to do so you get all the benefits of the
same entry tests except you can run them
on any CSI driver so currently I'm sure
other vendors are also running tests but
a lot of times they're kind of hard to
find and they may not be the same set of
tests so with this new framework what we
hope to do is have everyone running the
same set of kind of kubernetes e2e tests
and if you pass all of them it's at
least a basic understanding of yes we
support kubernetes okay
and as a little proof that we're
actually getting some adoption here's a
list of drivers that are currently
listed on the CSI documentation page and
I can assure you that this is not
actually a complete list as I've already
talked to a lot of groups at cube con
that have mentioned that they have CSI
drivers but I can't find them up there
so if you're one of those people and you
want people to find your driver add it
up there and of course I can't actually
attribute all of the success of CSI to
those two previous examples that I just
made but I think we're getting pretty
good adoption so far and
it's generally a good sign but the point
here is that adding value accelerates
adoption so if you want to get adoption
in your new fancy extensions mechanism
try adding value to that and just
supporting the old one without adding
new features to it so I just want to
reiterate again that these lessons
although they come from my experience
with CSI they can actually be taken and
applied to most arbitrary extensions or
specifications right they're actually
quite general and I'm sure these
patterns will pop up more in the future
so the three points I really want to
drive home or that having an open
development process really gets everyone
on the same page you in the process of
actually making changes to your
specification if it's open and
transparent you can actually build a
group of Advocates for that change that
can then go and like spread the gospel
about it afterwards if they were
involved in the process I also want to
talk remind you that the RPC definition
often isn't enough right we we might
need tools that exist external to the
RPC definition to enforce consistency
and to make sure that everyone's on the
same page when they're developing their
drivers also we want to give a
compelling reason for people to move to
this new paradigm we don't want to force
people over but when there's enough
value add they're going to move
themselves so what I'm trying to say is
that the specification isn't everything
in order for a successful specification
and extensions mechanism you actually
need this whole ecosystem of projects
that's support it as well as a whole

that help make it successful and so the
